Results Model #3 - Keras-BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers)


BERT stands for Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers. BERT was created by Google AI Language researchers for use in Natural Language Processing (NLP). One of the main benefits of using BERT for NLP is that it learns contextual relationships from words both to the left and right of a word. This differs from directional models which read text in a specific direction (i.e., left to right). BERT models come in different sizes (configurations of layers and specifications) that can be matched to the size of the data set and the desired speed and computing power required for classification. These models come pre-trained on text from Wikipedia and are fine-tuned based on the training data introduced and the use of an optimizer.


BERT Model Summary


For the classification of Fake News, the most efficient model was the smallest of the TensorFlow Small BERT group of models. It uses L=2 hidden layers (i.e., Transformer blocks), a hidden size of H=128, and A=2 attention heads. Using our expanded dataset, this produced a high accuracy at the minimal amount of training time and computing resources.

Results of training and testing model

Ivan's text goes here.


BERT Model Confusion Matrix

The model resulted in 5,771 true positives, and 6,300 true negatives. False positives were 151, and false negatives 419.

Classification Report

The model accuracy was 95% indicating that it contains more power to confirm the hypothesis about the disparity between fake and real news.
